title: British mum jailed in Bahrain for alleged adultery is granted 'quickie' divorce and allowed to return home
text:
News British mum jailed in Bahrain for alleged adultery is granted 'quickie' divorce and allowed to return home Hannah James, 26, was locked up after Jassim Alhaddar, 30, accused her of cheating - but he admitted to attacking her and claimed she bruises easily “because of her white skin” Share By John Ferguson Stephen Jones 07:19, 9 JAN 2017 Hannah James with her former partner Jassim Alhaddar in happier times (Photo: Facebook) Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
A British mum who was jailed in Bahrain for alleged adultery has been granted a 'quickie' divorce and is being allowed to fly home to the UK, it emerged late last night. 
MirrorOnline exclusively broke the news last Wednesday that Hannah James had been locked up after her husband accused her of cheating. 
Photos showed evidence of her having been bruised and battered by her husband - a claim which he admitted when it was put to him by The Mirror. 
After news of her ordeal gained international publicity Jassim Alhaddar, 30, withdrew the adultery claims and the charges were dropped. 
The Daily Record reports that last night the Bahraini government issued a bizarre defence for jailing Hannah – saying they were right to put her behind bars as she was accused of adultery. 
They also claimed she had NOT been abused by her violent husband. 
Hannah, 26, was imprisoned for a month after Alhaddar accused her of having an affair. 
He admitted to attacking her – claiming it was in self-defence and that she bruises easily “because of her white skin”. Jassim claimed Hannah bruised easily "because of her white skin" (Photo: Facebook) 
The mother-of-one was released on Friday after the case gain widespread media attention. 
Hannah, from Fraserburgh, Aberdeenshire, is now returning to the UK after being granted a divorce. 
It is not known whether her son will join her. 
In a statement sent to the Daily Record yesterday, a spokesman for the Bahraini authorities said: “With regards to the case of the British woman married to a Bahraini man who was detained on December 9, 2016, after her husband submitted a complaint of adultery against her. 
“The woman admitted to the act and she and her husband agreed to divorce. 
"On January 5, 2017, the complainant withdrew the complaint and the wife was released. All charges of adultery were dropped. 
“That same day, a complaint was submitted to the police containing the allegation made by the wife’s mother to the British Embassy that her daughter has been physically assaulted by her daughter’s husband and that she has been detained. Alleged images of the injuries suffered by Hannah James at the hands of her partner Jassim Alhaddar (Photo: Facebook) 
“The daughter went to the police station and denied the allegation made against her husband in the statement she gave to the police. 
“She contacted her mother and informed her she was in good health and is not facing problems with her husband. 
“She also added that all the issues have been settled and the two have agreed to divorce and that she would return to the United Kingdom. 
“There is a police record of a complaint from the wife against the husband of domestic violence and assault suffered between June and November 2016. 
"She later returned to the police station and withdrew the complaint. 
"Medical examinations and reports at the time of detention did not indicate any evidence of violence or mistreatment.” 
They added that the divorce would be finalised yesterday. 
The spokesman denied Hannah had been abused despite photographic evidence showing her sickening injuries. 
Alhaddar admitted hitting Hannah, claiming he acted in self defence. It is not clear if Hannah James will be allowed to leave with her son (Photo: JustGiving) 
He said her bruises only appeared because of her “white skin”, adding he only became violent when she was “caught cheating”. 
He said: “She has white skin so when I go to grab her, there will be bruises.” 
It was also claimed Alhaddar burned Hannah’s passport to stop her leaving. Read More 
However, the Bahraini authorities also seemed keen to rubbish this suggestion. 
The spokesman said: “She reported it to the police as lost. 
"It has been stated in police records that the husband has handed his wife her passport prior to the incident of its loss. 
“However, she is free to depart as soon as that issue is resolved with the British authorities.” 
The shocking story underlines the enormous risks women face travelling to strict Islamic countries ruled by Sharia law. Read More Bahrain prison attack: Gunmen storm jail killing policeman and freeing inmates convicted of terror offences 
Hannah, originally from Fraserburgh, emigrated to Bahrain last year with Alhaddar and their son Nelson, four. 
But it became a nightmare after she was arrested a month ago and detained in the strict Muslim state, where Sharia law is the basis of legislation. 
Her mum Shelley launched a desperate online plea for help and told how Hannah has been a victim of domestic abuse. 
Yesterday she said: “I can confirm the restriction placed on Hannah leaving Bahrain has been lifted. 
"The family thank every one of you that have supported them through this ordeal.” Like us on Facebook
